(CKPR, CJCD, BN) (Father's Sentencing Delayed)</p><p>Sentencing has been put off to May 19th in the case of a Leamington man convicted of drowning his two children.</p><p>Thomas Dewald pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the deaths of his 12-year-old son Christopher and his 10-year-old daughter Jennifer in Lake Erie last summer.</p><p>Sentencing was set for today, but Dewald's lawyer asked for more time to prepare psychiatric evidence. (CJBK, CFCO) (Witchcraft Sex)</p><p>Guelph O-P-P are investigating a bizarre case involving witchcraft, sex and drugs.</p><p>Police say a 27-year-old man formed a group based on the Wicca religion, enticing about a dozen teenage boys to his home.</p><p>Kenneth McMurray of Guelph is charged with sexual exploitation, sexual assault and possession of marijuana.</p><p>Police expect more victims to come forward. (CJOY, CKPC, CKKW) (Drugs Fire)</p><p>A farm house fire turned into a major drug bust for Guelph O-P-P.</p><p>Fire crews were called to a home just south of Alma yesterday.</p><p>The house was destroyed, but police recovered 82 marijuana plants and found a growing operation in the basement.</p><p>A 42-year-old Pilkington Township man faces several drug charges. (CKGL) (Ontario Budget)</p><p>Expect a good news, pre-election budget.</p><p>Analysts believe this afternoon's financial statement will focus on tax relief -- the cornerstone of the election platform the Harris Tories unveiled last week.</p><p>The budget will detail the timing of another 20 per cent cut to income tax rates, as well as a similar cut to the provincial portion of property taxes.</p><p>The first phase could come as early as July 1st, if the Tories are re-elected. (BN, CP) (New Hospital)</p><p>The province has approved construction of a new hospital in the Cobourg-Port Hope area.</p><p>The hospital will be located near Highway 4-0-1, east of Toronto, and will replace two older facilities in the communities.</p><p>There's no word on the final price tag.</p><p>But officials say the hospital could cost as much as 55-million dollars. "They've asked for some additional ones from out of province."</p><p>The Ministry of Natural Resources declared much of Northern Ontario a restricted fire zone, as more than four-dozen fires raged across the area.</p><p>The largest fire in the province, a 10,000-hectare blaze, led to the evacuation of the town of Beardmore near Lake Nipigon. About 300 residents have been taken to Geraldton, about 80 kilometres to the east.</p><p>At least seven lakeside cottages have been destroyed by the blaze.</p><p>In addition to the fire near Beardmore, a 500-hectare blaze near Chapleau is burning out of control. There is also another 60-hectare fire about 25 kilometres north of Hornepayne.</p><p>Recent mild winter and early snowmelt, the lack of rain this spring and unseasonably warm temperatures have contributed to the fire hazard.</p><p>CAUSED BY HUMANS</p><p>Every spring, lightning strikes cause a large number of fires. But since there's been no rain the last few weeks, "90 per cent of fires have been caused by humans," Legouffe said.</p><p>In Sioux Lookout, a fire is about four kilometres from the community of Bearskin Lake.</p><p>A wooden hydro pole burned by a forest fire resulted in power being cut to the town of White River and the three Hemlo gold mines yesterday.</p><p>About a dozen structures on a 115,000-volt transmission line just northwest of White River were damaged when the pole fell just before 1 p.m., said Ontario Hydro spokesman Al Manchee.</p><p>He said the power was expected to be back on by early today.</p><p>The fire, about 600 hectares in size, was burning eight kilometres west of White River and was not threatening the town.</p><p>The three mines there were able to get underground workers back to the surface using auxiliary diesel power.</p><p>Firefighters also struggled yesterday afternoon with stubborn forest fire south of Temagami.</p><p>But a Ministry of Natural Resources official said it could be another week or two before the blaze covering 76 hectares is completely out.</p><p>"There will be people committed to this for another week or two weeks unless we get substantial rain," said senior fire officer Brent Handley.</p><p>The fire began Sunday afternoon and forced more than 20 people to evacuate their homes. They returned Monday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier SANDIE RINALDO: Well, this weekend has turned into a wild one for people on both sides of the Canada US border. In this country, thousands are coping with high winds, heavy rain and wildfires. There's even snow. And the US heartland is taking another pounding from tornadoes with about three-dozen twisters in the latest onslaught. More from CTV's Manitoba bureau chief Jill Macyshon.

JILL MACYSHON (Reporter): This stretch of the Great Plains known as Tornado Alley, again living up to its name.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: Oh, my god. His cows are sitting right here. And you can hear the tornado sirens going off.

MACYSHON: Severe storms stretching from Minnesota to Texas caused flash flooding. The National Guard helped rescue ten people from their homes and cars. In Oklahoma, twisters damaged homes and knocked out power. One in Kansas blew 34 freight cars off tracks. Wind a menace in parts of Canada, too, with warnings stretching from southern Saskatchewan to northwestern Ontario. Gusts to 90 kilometres per hour downed power lines. This May long weekend, some trying to escape it all were instead stuck in the middle of it.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: What can we do?

MACYSHON: Here in southern Manitoba, the weather warnings have brought out fewer campers. There's been cancellations due to the high winds, rain and snow. That's right, snow, which start falling in central Manitoba and Saskatchewan early Sunday morning, welcome news to the residents of Black Lake where a forest fire forced 600 people from their homes. The snow helps bring the flames under control. In BC, lightning from storms touched off at least five new wildfires, this at a time when crews are already busy fighting what is being called the province's biggest ever fire at Little Bobtail Lake. It has led to evacuations and now officials are searching for suspects. This fire was man made. In Manitoba, the weekend weather warning will extend into Monday when the driving rain is expected to turn into blowing snow. Jill Macyshon, CTV News, Winnipeg.

It wasn't known how much the rebuilding will cost.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>"It's not something we look forward to in our economy, because things are tough enough right across the country right now," Timmins Mayor Victor Power said yesterday. "And we're certainly going to feel this here."</p><p>Malette's survival is a major concern to a city hobbled by the recession since 1990.</p><p>The plant, which recently underwent a $60-million expansion, produces oriented strand board -- a new plywood replacement that is a favourite with the construction trade.</p><p>Built in 1972, it was once the biggest mill in North America. The expansion tripled its output and local politicians lobbied hard to help Malette obtain new logging rights.</p><p>Less than a week ago, a nearby forest fire put the mill and the city at risk, with Power declaring a state of emergency that remained in effect until Monday.</p><p>But as the forest fire was under control, a fire erupted within the plant early yesterday. A hydraulic line exploded causing a power press to overheat.</p><p>The blaze was pounded into submission by waves of water-bomber attacks. The aircraft were called in after dozens of firefighters trying to protect the mill were frustrated by a sputtering water supply -- the mill is west of the city and beyond municipal water mains.</p><p>Smoke poured from the building as municipal firefighters and desperate plant employees used tanker trucks to shuttle water to the scene. Pumps were also used to pull water from a ditch and the nearby Mattagami River.</p><p>"This morning, when I drove in at 6 a.m., the flames were leaping 10 and 20 feet out of the top of the building," said Len Gillis, a reporter for MCTV.</p><p>"The smoke was thick, black, acrid smoke that covered a wide swath of area. You could barely see the sunrise through the haze."</p><p>A forest fire devoured 200 hectares of Northern Ontario timberland while licking at the edges of the Malette plant last week. That blaze, which peaked last Thursday, forced the evacuation of 400 residents -- most from trailer parks on the outskirts of town.</p><p>Provincial officials said the risk of more fires, particularly in northeastern Ontario, remains extreme.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "They've asked for some additional ones from out of province."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CANADIAN PRESS</p></bodyText></section><p>The Ministry of Natural Resources declared much of Northern Ontario a restricted fire zone as more than four-dozen fires raged across the area.</p><p>The largest fire in the province, a 10,000-hectare blaze, led to the evacuation of the town of Beardmore near Lake Nipigon.</p><p>About 300 residents have been taken to Geraldton, about 80 kilometres to the east.</p><p>At least seven lakeside cottages have been destroyed by the blaze.</p><p>In addition to the fire near Beardmore, a 500-hectare blaze near Chapleau is burning out of control. There is also another 60-hectare fire burning about 25 kilometres north of Hornepayne.</p><p>Recent mild winter and early snowmelt, the lack of rain this spring and unseasonably warm temperatures have all contributed to the fire hazard.</p><p>Every spring, lightning strikes cause a large number of forest fires. But since there's been no rain for the last few weeks, "90 per cent of the fires have been caused by humans," Legouffe said.</p><p>In Sioux Lookout, a fire is about four kilometres from the community of Bearskin Lake.</p><p>A wooden hydro pole burned by a forest fire resulted in power being cut to the town of White River and the three Hemlo gold mines Tuesday afternoon.</p><p>About a dozen structures on a 115,000-volt transmission line just northwest of White River were damaged when the pole fell just before 1 p.m., said Ontario Hydro spokesman Al Manchee.</p><p>He said the power was expected to be back on by midnight Tuesday.</p><p>The fire, about 600 hectares in size, was burning eight kilometres west of White River and was not threatening the town.</p><p>The three mines there were able to get underground workers back to the surface using auxiliary diesel power.</p><p>Firefighters struggled Tuesday afternoon with a stubborn forest fire south of Temagami.</p><p>But a Ministry of Natural Resources official said Tuesday afternoon it could be another week or two before the blaze, covering 76 hectares, is completely out.</p><p>The fire began Sunday afternoon and forced more than 20 people to evacuate their homes. They returned Monday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5KB9-C621-F0R9-G560-00000-00Cenovus has Strong Second-Quarter Operational Performance2016-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisCenovus has Strong Second-Quarter Operational PerformanceMarketwire (Canada)

CALGARY, AB--(Marketwired - July 28, 2016) - Cenovus Energy Inc. (TSX: CVE) (NYSE: CVE) continued to deliver strong and reliable operating performance in the second quarter of 2016. The company remains on track with its plans to bring on two new oil sands expansion phases and achieve up to $500 million in capital, operating and general and administrative (G&A) cost reductions compared with its original 2016 budget.

"We've achieved significant sustainable improvements in our cost structure over the last year and a half, and we'll remain vigilant on costs to maximize our competitive position in this challenging and volatile commodity price environment," said Brian Ferguson, Cenovus President & Chief Executive Officer. "Our reduced cost base and strong operational performance, coupled with an improvement in benchmark oil and natural gas prices from the lows reached earlier this year, contributed to a solid second quarter."

Key developments

Overvew

Cenovus's strong operational performance in the second quarter of 2016 included a 9% increase in combined oil sands production and a 24% decrease in per-barrel oil sands operating costs compared with the same quarter of 2015. The company's year-over-year financial performance was negatively impacted by the significant decline in crude oil and natural gas prices from the previous year's quarter. However, an increase in crude oil and natural gas prices from the multi-year lows reached in the first three months of 2016 contributed to improved cash flow compared with the first quarter of this year.

Ol productonProduction at Cenovus's Foster Creek oil sands project averaged approximately 65,000 bbls/d net in the second quarter, 11% higher than in the same period a year earlier when a precautionary shutdown due to nearby forest fire activity reduced volumes by approximately 10,500 bbls/d net. Operations at Foster Creek have not been affected by forest fire activity in 2016. June production averaged just under 69,000 bbls/d net as Cenovus continued to ramp up new sustaining well pads at Foster Creek and brought a number of wells that were down for servicing back online, as planned. At the end of June, the company had commissioned the majority of the facilities for its Foster Creek expansion phase G, which is on track to be completed and add incremental oil volumes in the third quarter, with ramp-up expected over an 18-month period. Cenovus continues to anticipate exiting 2016 with Foster Creek production above 70,000 bbls/d net.

Production at Christina Lake averaged approximately 78,000 bbls/d net in the second quarter, an 8% increase from the same period a year earlier. The increase was largely due to the completion of the Christina Lake optimization project in late 2015 and the reliable performance of the operation's facilities. Christina Lake phase F remains on track for first oil in the third quarter and is expected to ramp up over a 12-month period. During the second quarter, Cenovus successfully commissioned its 100 megawatt Christina Lake cogeneration power plant, with full ramp-up expected in the third quarter. The company is spending a small amount of capital to complete detailed engineering on Christina Lake phase G and is in the process of rebidding work on the project. Cenovus expects to provide more information at the time of its 2017 budget announcement in December about the potential to restart phase G, which was put on hold in late 2014 due to the decline in oil prices.

"Given the strength of our balance sheet and financial position as well as our high level of confidence that the cost reductions we've achieved will be largely sustainable, I'm optimistic about the potential to resume construction on some of our deferred projects," said Ferguson. "However, we still need additional clarity on federal fiscal and regulatory policies that could impact our operating environment."

In the second quarter, Cenovus undertook precautionary staff evacuations at its Christina Lake and Pelican Lake operations due to nearby forest fire activity. While non-essential personnel at Christina Lake were sent home for several days in May due to heightened forest fire risk, essential staff remained at site and safely continued full production. In June, a forest fire near Pelican Lake prompted the orderly shutdown and precautionary evacuation of all personnel from site for two days. Operations and staffing were restored to normal levels in a safe and timely manner.

"I'm extremely pleased with the composure and professionalism our teams have displayed in carrying out these precautionary measures to protect our people and operations this wildfire season," said Kieron McFadyen, Cenovus Executive Vice-President & President, Upstream Oil & Gas. "Fortunately, everyone has remained safe, and our infrastructure has not been impacted by forest fires. Our thoughts go out to everyone who was affected by the fire that devastated Fort McMurray this spring."

Cost reductonsCenovus remains on track with its target to reduce capital, operating and G&A costs by up to $500 million this year compared with its original 2016 budget. The company expects about two-thirds of its realized cost reductions achieved since the end of 2014 will be sustainable even in a higher commodity price environment.

"I want to acknowledge the hard work of everyone at Cenovus in finding ways to reduce costs over the last year and a half," said Ferguson. "This has made us stronger and more financially resilient, and we'll continue to look for further efficiencies in the months ahead."

Per-barrel operating costs continued to decline in the second quarter, compared with the same period in 2015, including a 24% reduction in combined oil sands operating costs to $8.06 per barrel (bbl). Oil sands non-fuel operating costs fell by 19% to $6.54/bbl primarily as a result of higher production volumes, better prioritization of repairs and maintenance and improved well pump performance. During the second quarter, Christina Lake recorded a larger credit under Alberta's greenhouse gas emissions regulations than in the second quarter of last year, which also helped to reduce operating costs.

As previously announced, Cenovus completed its planned workforce reduction program in the second quarter, bringing total staff reductions since the end of 2014 to 31%. In the second quarter, Cenovus recorded severance costs of approximately $19 million related to its 2016 workforce reductions.

Fnancal performanceThe year-over-year decline in West Texas Intermediate (WTI), Western Canadian Select (WCS) and AECO natural gas prices of 21%, 30% and 53%, respectively, as well as a decline in average market crack spreads contributed to a decrease in second-quarter operating cash flow to $541 million, 42% lower than in the same period of 2015. Upstream operating cash flow was down 45% to $348 million.

The company's refining and marketing business had strong operating performance in the second quarter, with operating cash flow of $193 million. This represents a $216 million improvement from the first quarter of the year, primarily driven by a recovery in market crack spreads and better utilization rates. Year over year, operating cash flow from refining and marketing was down 36% in the second quarter of 2016, primarily due to lower average market crack spreads driven by higher storage levels for refined product and a 75% narrowing of the Brent-WTI price differential.

Cenovus ended the second quarter of 2016 with cash and cash equivalents of approximately $3.8 billion. Including $4.0 billion in undrawn capacity under its committed credit facility, the company has nearly $8 billion in liquidity available, with no debt maturing until the fourth quarter of 2019. At the end of the second quarter, the company's net debt to capitalization was 17% compared with 28% at the end of the second quarter of 2015. Its net debt to adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) was 1.9 times on a trailing 12-month basis, compared with 1.5 times at the end of the same period a year ago.

Cenovus has an active hedging program and will evaluate additional hedging opportunities for 2017 and 2018 to help maintain its financial resilience.

Gudance updateCenovus has updated its 2016 full-year guidance to reflect actual results for the first six months of the year and the company's estimates for the second half of 2016. The revisions primarily reflect expectations for continued improvement in company-wide operating costs and lower anticipated capital spending at Cenovus's oil sands business. Updated guidance is available at cenovus.com under "Investors."

Brunswick, the number of fires in the province so far this year is down considerably.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The number of blazes and the amount of land destroyed have almost been cut in half when compared with last year's figures, a spokesman for the National Resources Department said Tuesday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>By this time last year, there had been 200 outbreaks in the province's woods, resulting in 329 hectares being burned.</p><p>Spokesman Brent Roy said there have only been 115 forest fires so far this year, destroying 186 Firefighters battled to douse a series of wildfires fueled by high winds, scorching temperatures and dry vegetation, which have forced tens of thousands of Californians to flee their homes.A blaze scorching sections of the Angeles National Forest, in southern California, two huge infernos in the central part of the state and another fire further north have displaced entire towns."Our fire activity has definitely picked up in past weeks in number and severity," said Daniel Berlant, a spokesman for the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.The Angeles forest fire -- dubbed "Blue Cut" -- has devoured 31,000 acres (12,545 hectares), an area more than twice the size of Bermuda, and is just four percent contained.The fire has been spreading at such an alarming pace that it appears as if it were "running at you," according to Michael Lopez, a spokesman for fire information website Inciweb.

CRESTLINE, Calif. - The Latest on California wildfires (all times local):

8 p.m.

Hundreds of homes are under evacuation orders and thousands are threatened by a surging wildfire in the San Bernardino Mountains near Hesperia.

San Bernardino County sheriff's officials and the U.S. Forest Service tell the Los Angeles Times that 375 homes were under mandatory evacuation orders on Monday night.

Authorities say about 5,000 more are under voluntary evacuation orders.

No homes have yet burned and no one has been injured by the blaze that broke out on Sunday.

___

5:15 p.m.

Dozens of homes have now been ordered evacuated from a growing wildfire in the mountains of Southern California.

Mandatory evacuations have been called for at least 25 homes because of the 7-square-mile blaze in the San Bernardino National Forest.

More than 5,000 homes are under voluntarily evacuation advisories because of the fire.

The blaze broke out Sunday above the high-desert city of Hesperia. That's about 60 miles northeast of Los Angeles.

___

9:50 a.m.

Smoke from a growing wildfire in the mountains of Southern California is casting a hazy pall in Las Vegas, more than 200 miles away.

County officials in southern Nevada on Monday issued an air quality advisory due to smoke from the 7-square-mile blaze in the San Bernardino National Forest.

Fire officials estimated containment at just 5 per cent on the wildfire that erupted shortly after noon Sunday in the San Bernardino Mountains above the high-desert city of Hesperia. That's about 60 miles northeast of Los Angeles.

The air advisory is in effect in southern Nevada through Tuesday.

The Clark County Department of Air Quality says air is unhealthy for sensitive groups, including young children, senior citizens people and with respiratory problems and cardiac disease.

____

8:15 a.m.

A wildfire in the San Bernardino National Forest east of Los Angeles has tripled in size to 7 square miles.

The blaze in the San Bernardino Mountains east of Silverwood Lake and south of the high desert city of Hesperia grew from 1,500 acres on Sunday to 4,500 acres early Monday. Containment is estimated at just 5 per cent.

Some 400 firefighters are working the blaze and more have been ordered.

The fire erupted shortly after noon Sunday. The cause is unknown.

Among other fires in California, the 18-day-old blaze near Big Sur has burned nearly 90 square miles and is 45 per cent contained.

More than 5,000 firefighters are on the lines of the fire, which was ignited by an illegal campfire and has destroyed 57 homes and damaged three others.

urn:contentItem:5VN2-WJN1-F103-33TY-00000-00Winter was frigid because the polar vortex got 'drunk'2019-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 0Winter was frigid because the polar vortex got 'drunk'

The mere mention of the term "polar vortex" elicits thoughts of bitterly cold temperatures and dangerous wind chills. Most people are aware that the frigid air in the Northern Hemisphere is coming directly from the Arctic region, yet they don't know why polar vortexes happen.

DON'T MISS: Some answers to questions behind Hamilton's snow day policy

Not surprisingly, this has led to some rather heated debate. One side of the argument claims that the polar vortex is a result of climate change and human activity. The other side suggests this is a natural phenomenon that proves global warming is false and that humans are not involved in altering our climate.

The truth is the former is correct. But trying to convince someone to accept this reality might be a difficult challenge. Thankfully, when it comes to the cause of the polar vortex, there is a relatively easy - and for some, relatable - explanation. Quite simply, the polar vortex gets drunk.

MORE: 'Epic' storm brings blizzards, floods, tornado to mid-US

My research expertise is in microbiology, immunology and chemical mechanisms of molecular interaction (think antibiotics).

As a science communicator, one of my greatest hurdles is defining the intricacies of research into language with which people can understand. This means going deep into the literature and finding the mechanism behind the result. It also means having a deep level of knowledge in a variety of different science branches.

In some cases, the information can be difficult to convey to a wider audience. But when it comes to the polar vortex, it's not difficult at all.

A close examination of the chemistry associated with the onset of these cold snaps reveals a near-perfect resemblance to a chemical shift our bodies encounter during alcohol consumption. The results reveal that both humans and the planet are similarly susceptible to unexpected and unwanted movements.

Unstable masses

Most of us can recognize when someone has had too much to drink. Their speech is slurred and they have troubles with their balance. This latter symptom is why the walk-and-turn sobriety test is effective - an inebriated person has trouble moving in a straight line.

Maintaining posture and balance is a complicated neurological process. Research has revealed that one molecule, gamma aminobutyric acid (GABA), is necessary for us to achieve this goal. Our brains use this neurotransmitter to help control the signals to our muscles, particularly when we feel the effects of gravity or being pushed by another person.

When we drink alcohol, GABA helps us preserve our balance and posture. But once we end up losing the necessary levels of GABA needed to keep us upright, we sway, stagger and stumble. Only when we've sobered up and increased our GABA levels are we able to regain our balance.

A similar process occurs in the Arctic.

Cold sober

The polar vortex, officially known as the stratospheric polar vortex (SPV), is a stable air mass that tends to stay put when it's cold sober. In the same way we feel an internal heat during alcohol consumption, the region can warm up with an infiltration of air from the south, better known as a sudden stratospheric warming. When this happens, the steadiness of the vortex is challenged.

Much like our brains have GABA to maintain stability, the SPV also has a chemical that helps to maintain stability. It's ozone.

When levels remain high, the vortex stays in place. But should the levels drop, then the vortex starts to sway, stagger and then stumble southward, a process known as outward eddy transport. Depending on how low the ozone levels drop, the vortex can stretch well into the southern United States and Europe. Eventually, the SPV sobers up, the ozone levels recover, and the air mass stays up north. But this recovery can be slow and leave those affected freezing for weeks instead of days.

As to what causes the ozone loss, it's a reaction with a variety of chemicals in the air. Researchers can observe the process in real time and have found that the offenders are not alcoholic in nature but happen to be compounds that contain nitrogen and chlorine. The Earth produces these chemicals in the form of volcanic output and forest fire emissions, and this can lead to a drunk polar region.

But the frequency of these events has increased from one every few years to one very few months. There must be another perpetrator.

Thanks to real-time examinations of polar vortex movements over the last 20 years, we can easily finger the culprit: industrial air pollution. These commercial activities produce more than enough of the nitrogen and chlorine chemicals to reduce ozone levels and cause those drunken staggers. The data clearly shows that the blame for the rise in those cold blasts falls squarely on us.

As this winter's supply of polar vortex events comes to an end, so should the debate over whether the polar vortex is real - it is - and whether these movements are due to human activity - they are. Until we find ways to reduce our dependence on ozone-removing chemicals, all we can do is hope for the best and brace for the worst.

urn:contentItem:5KDW-7HT1-DY9S-T3NX-00000-00Nova Scotia restricts forest access amid 'high' risk of more wildfires: minister2016-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisNATIONAL,ATLANTICNova Scotia restricts forest access amid 'high' risk of more wildfires: ministerN.S. at 'high' risk of more fires: ministerAdina BresgeThe Canadian Press

HALIFAX - As crews battle three wildfires in western Nova Scotia, the province is restricting activity within forests in a bid to keep more bone-dry woods from going up in flames.

"We can manage the fires we've got. If we get many more, it's going to cause great concern for us," Natural Resources Minister Lloyd Hines said Monday, who warned the risk of more fires is "high."

Restrictions on hiking, camping fishing, use of off-highway vehicles, and certain commercial activities will come into effect at noon on Tuesday.

"The primary objective here ... is to enlist the public's help in trying to reduce the risk," Hines said in an interview. "The reality is, most of the fires we're aware of that start in the province start with human activity."

Hines said the fires in Maitland Bridge and Greenfield have been contained at roughly 21 hectares and five hectares respectively. The blaze at Seven Mile Lake is considered out of control and has grown to 140 hectares.

The fires in Annapolis and Queens counties broke out last Thursday.

The minister said some areas are facing the driest conditions the province has seen in 15 years, which was also the last time similar restrictions were imposed on forest access.

Hines said the province is directing "all available resources" to fight the fire at Seven Mile Lake at a cost of approximately $200,000 per day.

"One could say it's burning through our resources," Hines said. "There's also a safety issue. We've got our (fire crews) working in dangerous conditions , and we don't need any other fires to start somewhere else in our province."

New Brunswick and Newfoundland and Labrador have deployed water bombers to aid the effort at Seven Mile Lake.

Walter Fanning, an executive director at the Department of Natural Resources, said the province can call on the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre if it needs additional back up, or recruit resources from New England.

Hines said the restriction will be reassessed in two weeks. Until then, he acknowledged the restrictions may pose an inconvenience for Nova Scotians, but does not think tourism in the province will take a dramatic hit.

"There are a lot of places in Nova Scotia for people to see that doesn't require going through our woods," he said. "Our beaches and our parks -- all of that is still open."

Hines said forestry, mining and other commercial industries will have to obtain permits to work on Crown land. Hunters and fishermen will also require travel permits.

urn:contentItem:5D83-4CV1-DY9S-T3TH-00000-00Near-record timber losses as officials start adding up B.C. fire season2014-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisWEATHER,PRAIRIES/BCNear-record timber losses as officials start adding up B.C. fire seasonNear-record timber losses for B.C. fire seasonThe Canadian Press

VICTORIA - An overheated forest fire season in British Columbia resulted in a near-record loss of timber - the third highest total since 1950 when the government started keeping track.

Chief provincial fire information officer Kevin Skrepnek said Monday 1,424 fires consumed more than 3,590 square kilometres of forest this season.

Skrepnek said an intense provincewide hot weather spell in July, where temperatures soared to 40 C in some areas, dried out forests and contributed to extreme fire conditions that lasted much of the summer.

"When you look at the statistics in terms of the number of fires we're had, we've had a little over 1,400 - 1,424 - that's actually below average in terms of the number of fires," he said. "So, what we saw this year was a below average number of fires, but in terms of the area burned, quite above normal."

The largest fire of the year occurred near the Chelaslie River near Burns Lake, consuming 1,330 square kilometres. It's still burning, but 75 per cent contained.

"We had a pretty steady season - nothing spectacular - until the second week in July, and then we had an unseasonably high system come in and add really hot temperatures, record-breaking temperatures," said Skrepnek. "We had a high-pressure system that stretched into the Yukon. That was what set the season off."

Skrepnek said cooler temperatures and rain showers this week are expected to signal the conclusion of the core fire season.

The top two B.C. fire seasons were recorded in 1958 when fires burned 8,590 square kilometres and in 1961 when 4,830 square kilometres of forest land was burned.

Skrepnek says the provincial government has spent more than $293 million fighting fires this year, but the government allocated just $63 million in its budget to cover fire costs.

Last year, the province spent $122 million fighting 1,857 fires.

urn:contentItem:5VN0-3KH1-JB75-91T0-00000-00Winter was frigid because the polar vortex got 'drunk'2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisWinter was frigid because the polar vortex got 'drunk'Jason Tetro, Visiting Scientist, University of Guelph

Alcohol consumption provides a useful metaphor for understanding the science behind the polar vortex.

The mere mention of the term "polar vortex" elicits thoughts of bitterly cold temperatures and dangerous wind chills. Most people are aware that the frigid air in the Northern Hemisphere is coming directly from the Arctic region, yet they don't know why polar vortexes happen.

Not surprisingly, this has led to some rather heated debate. One side of the argument claims that the polar vortex is a result of climate change and human activity. The other side suggests this is a natural phenomenon that proves global warming is false and that humans are not involved in altering our climate.

The truth is the former is correct. But trying to convince someone to accept this reality might be a difficult challenge. Thankfully, when it comes to the cause of the polar vortex, there is a relatively easy - and for some, relatable - explanation. Quite simply, the polar vortex gets drunk.

My research expertise is in microbiology, immunology and chemical mechanisms of molecular interaction (think antibiotics).

As a science communicator, one of my greatest hurdles is defining the intricacies of research into language with which people can understand. This means going deep into the literature and finding the mechanism behind the result. It also means having a deep level of knowledge in a variety of different science branches.

In some cases, the information can be difficult to convey to a wider audience. But when it comes to the polar vortex, it's not difficult at all.

A close examination of the chemistry associated with the onset of these cold snaps reveals a near-perfect resemblance to a chemical shift our bodies encounter during alcohol consumption. The results reveal that both humans and the planet are similarly susceptible to unexpected and unwanted movements.

Unstable masses

Most of us can recognize when someone has had too much to drink. Their speech is slurred and they have troubles with their balance. This latter symptom is why the walk-and-turn sobriety test is effective - an inebriated person has trouble moving in a straight line.

Maintaining posture and balance is a complicated neurological process. Research has revealed that one molecule, gamma aminobutyric acid (GABA), is necessary for us to achieve this goal. Our brains use this neurotransmitter to help control the signals to our muscles, particularly when we   feel the effects of gravity or being pushed by another person.

When we drink alcohol, GABA helps us preserve our balance and posture. But once we end up losing the necessary levels of GABA needed to keep us upright, we sway, stagger and stumble. Only when we've sobered up and increased our GABA levels are we able to regain our balance.

A similar process occurs in the Arctic.

Cold sober

The polar vortex, officially known as the stratospheric polar vortex (SPV), is a stable air mass that tends to stay put when it's cold sober. In the same way we feel an internal heat during alcohol consumption, the region can warm up with an infiltration of air from the south, better known as a   sudden stratospheric warming. When this happens, the steadiness of the vortex is challenged.

Much like our brains have GABA to maintain stability, the SPV also has a chemical that helps to maintain stability. It's ozone.

When levels remain high, the vortex stays in place. But should the levels drop, then the vortex starts to sway, stagger and then stumble southward, a process known as   outward eddy transport. Depending on how low the ozone levels drop, the vortex can stretch well into the southern United States and Europe. Eventually, the SPV sobers up, the ozone levels recover, and the air mass stays up north. But this recovery can be slow and leave those affected freezing for weeks instead of days.

As to what causes the ozone loss, it's a reaction with a variety of chemicals in the air. Researchers can observe the process in real time and have found that the offenders are not alcoholic in nature but happen to be   compounds that contain nitrogen and chlorine. The Earth produces these chemicals in the form of   volcanic output and forest fire emissions, and this can lead to a drunk polar region.

But the frequency of these events has increased from   one every few years to one very few months. There must be another perpetrator.

Thanks to real-time examinations of polar vortex movements over   the last 20 years, we can easily finger the culprit: industrial air pollution. These commercial activities produce more than enough of the nitrogen and chlorine chemicals to reduce ozone levels and cause those drunken staggers. The data clearly shows that the blame for the rise in those cold blasts falls squarely on us.

As this winter's supply of polar vortex events comes to an end, so should the debate over whether the polar vortex is real - it is - and whether these movements are due to human activity - they are. Until we find ways to reduce our dependence on ozone-removing chemicals, all we can do is hope for the best and brace for the worst.

(CP) - An accidental blaze that destroyed much of a huge wood-processing mill could has put 175 employees out of work, pinching an economy that relies heavily on forestry.</p><p nitf:lede="true">It will take about six months to get the Malette Strandboard mill up and running again, officials said. It wasn't known how much the rebuilding will cost.</p><p>"It's not something we look forward to in our economy because things are tough enough right across the country right now,'' Timmins Mayor Victor Power said Tuesday. "And we're certainly going to feel this here.''</p><p>Malette's survival is a major concern in Timmins, a city hobbled by the recession that started in 1990.</p><p>The plant, which recently underwent a $60-million expansion, produces oriented strand board - a new plywood replacement that is a favorite with the construction trade.</p><p>Built in 1972, it was once the biggest mill in North America. The expansion tripled its output and local politicians lobbied hard to help Malette obtain new logging rights.</p><p>Less than a week ago, a nearby forest fire put the mill and the city at risk, with Power declaring a state of emergency that remained in effect until Monday.</p><p>But as the forest fire was under control, a fire erupted within the plant early Tuesday. A hydraulic line exploded causing a power press to overheat, officials said.</p><p>The blaze was pounded into submission by waves of water-bomber attacks.</p><p>The aircraft were called in after dozens of firefighters trying to protect the mill were frustrated by a sputtering water supply - the mill is west of the city and beyond municipal water mains.</p><p>Smoke poured from the building as municipal firefighters and desperate plant employees used tanker trucks to shuttle water to the scene. Pumps were also used to pull water from a ditch and the nearby Mattagami River.</p><p>"This morning when I drove in at 6 a.m., the flames were leaping 10 and 20 feet out of the top of the building,'' said Len Gillis, a reporter for MCTV.</p><p>"The smoke was thick, black, acrid smoke that covered a wide swath of area . . . You could barely see the sunrise through the haze.''</p><p>A forest fire devoured 200 hectares of Northern Ontario timberland while licking at the edges of the Malette plant last week. That blaze, which peaked Thursday, forced the evacuation of 400 residents - most from trailer parks on the outskirts of town.</p><p>Provincial officials said the risk of more fires, particularly in northeastern Ontario, remains extreme.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5NWX-NGV1-JCMN-Y1W5-00000-00Spreading wildfire in Arizona forces evacuation of thousands2017-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisSpreading wildfire in Arizona forces evacuation of thousands

Jun 28, 2017( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) Firefighters in Southern Arizona are struggling today with a fast-moving wildfire that has already burned over 21,000 acres. Called the Goodwin Fire, it has forced the evacuation of thousands of residents. The Goodwin Fire is still too dangerous for fire officials to make a good assessment of the conditions or to even find out how many structures have been destroyed.

The intensity of the fast-growing fire through the densely forested region has prompted Arizona Governor Doug Ducey to declare a state of emergency in Yavapai County, reports Reuters[1].Over 500 firefighters are fighting the wildfire burning in communities around Prescott, a mountain city about 100 miles (160.9 kilometers) north of Phoenix. The fire has so far charred about 28 square miles (73 square kilometers), all the while being fanned by winds whipping up to 35 mph (56 kph). The fire forced the evacuation of Mayer and Dewey-Humboldt along with several other communities, as well as causing one of the main roads into Prescott to be closed. Dewey-Humboldt has about 4,000 residents, while Mayer has about 1,400. People living in this region still have memories of the 2013 wildfire that killed 19 members of an elite firefighting crew. "It's scary because we're coming up on the four-year anniversary of the Yarnell Hill fire — there's still a lot of fresh memories," said Arizona state Sen. Karen Fann, who lives in Prescott and represents the area where the fire is burning, reports ABC News[2]. John Pierson, the incident commander for the Goodwin Fire told AZ Central[3] the fire had claimed at least some structures around Piney Flat, but he could not say if any homes were destroyed. The fire was only contained about 1.0 percent this morning. Pierson did emphasize that firefighters were doing everything possible to prevent a repeat of the 2013 Yarnell disaster. Fires burning in other states across the WestThe Brian Head Fire burning nearly 300 miles (483 km) south of Salt Lake City has grown overnight, charring an additional 4,000 acres. It now covers over 54,000 acres (21,853 hectares). The Brian Head Fire has destroyed at least 13 homes and forced the evacuation of 1,500 people as it continues to rage for the 12th day. In Washington state, firefighters are battling three fires near Wenatchee that had grown to about 37 square miles (95 square kilometers) as of Wednesday. California also has several wildfires going, including the one that destroyed the home of "Big Bang Theory" star Johnny Galecki on a ranch in the San Luis Obispo area. In Idaho, state fire officials are praising the quick responses of farmers and others to the 20 or so wildfires sparked by lightning. By keeping the fires under control, they prevented them from becoming major blazes. And again, a quick reminder is in order - Be careful when you're out in the forests and woodlands, folks. Unless you have lived through a forest fire, you will have no idea of the unbelievable size and destructive power of that wall of flames. urn:contentItem:4J9M-8XF0-TX77-D2BT-00000-00Province rejects plan to log ravaged forest2002-03-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:18ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Province rejects plan to log ravaged forestJohnnie BachuskyRed Deer Express

The Alberta government has denied a Sunpine Forest Products application to log burned trees from a fire-ravaged section of the Bighorn Wildland Recreation area.

"To harvest that area they (Sunpine) needed to show a benefit for wildlife to be able to harvest," said Butch Shenfield, provincial forestry area manager. "The economic benefit of taking the trees out and utilizing them is secondary to the wildlife concerns. Their application did not demonstrate there would be a benefit for wildlife in there."

The province's decision delighted environmental groups, who have argued the prime protection area is already too heavily logged.

"The intent of the integrated resource plan for there is to maintain important environmental values," said Tamaini Snaith, Alberta Wilderness Association conservation specialist. "I think logging, salvage or otherwise violates that intent. Burnt trees have a huge ecological value and shouldn't be removed just because they can be sold."

Tom Daniels, Sunpine's community affairs forester, said the company was hoping the salvage operation in the 865-hectare area, which is outside its approved forest management area, would mitigate the company's enormous economic losses from last fall's Dogrib Creek blaze, the largest forest fire in the region in more than 60 years. To access the burnt timber, the company had planned to build a temporary bridge across the Red Deer River.

Daniels said the company has yet to tabulate its total losses from the forest fire. He said the provincial decision leaves the company without any alternative strategies.

However, he added Sunpine may make another application next year with a plan that may combine research and harvesting strategies.

DISCOVERY AIR INC ("DA.A-V") - Operating Results For Second Quarter Ending April 30, 2006

PRESIDENT'S COMMENTS

This quarter we successfully closed our first public offering issuing 7,700,000 Class A common shares for proceeds of $3.8 million before share issue costs. Shortly afterwards our company began trading on the TSX Venture Exchange under the trading symbol DA.A.

On April 9, 2006 we signed an agreement in principle to acquire a second niche aviation company, Great Slave Helicopters Ltd. (GSHL). GSHL owns a fleet of 70 light and medium helicopters that service locations throughout Canada with particular emphasis in the Canadian Arctic. We are well on our way to closing this transaction and obtaining the necessary regulatory and other approvals. GSHL is well known in the industry for its outstanding service and dedicated employees who upon completion of this transaction will be offered share participation in Discovery Air.

Our first acquisition, Hicks and Lawrence Limited provides aerial forest fire management services in Northern Ontario. Consequently a majority of its revenue is earned during the forest fire season which normally commences May and concludes towards the end of September. Therefore, for the six month period ended April 30, 2006, revenues were nominal while expenses were incurred throughout that time to maintain the aircraft and update the facilities. Due to this seasonality of revenues and expenses, Hicks and Lawrence produced a loss during the first six months which resulted in a consolidated loss for Discovery Air of $448,000 for the quarter and $985,000 on a year-to-date basis. As in the previous year we expect this loss to be eliminated in the third quarter.

Discovery Air was incorporated to provide a vehicle for the consolidation of profitable Canadian niche aviation companies to realize synergies and economies of scale thereby creating a profitable and diversified company which can deliver safe, professional air services to clients in selected niche markets. I believe GSHL fits this mission perfectly and we look forward to GSHL joining our group.

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS

The following management's discussion and analysis of financial condition for the second quarter of fiscal 2006 should be read in conjunction with the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements and related notes for the period ended April 30, 2006 included herein and the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements and related notes for the period ended January 31, 2006, which are available on SEDAR at www.sedar.com.

Business Profile

Discovery Air Inc. (the "Corporation") was incorporated on November 12, 2004. On December 21, 2004, the Corporation acquired 50% of the outstanding shares of Hicks & Lawrence Limited (H & L) and acquired the remaining 50% of the outstanding shares on August 16, 2005. H & L is an Ontario-based aviation company focused on providing air services to niche markets in the province. H & L currently has two government contracts to provide air services in support of a forest fire management program. Demand for these services normally commences in the month of May continuing through the summer months, where demand reaches its highest and reduces in September. As a result, the operations of the Corporation are subject to seasonal variations. Operating results therefore vary from quarter to quarter, and results of one quarter may not be indicative of results that may be achieved for another quarter or the full year.

Prior to the Corporation's initial 50% acquisition, H & L had no business activities as its Transport Canada operating certificate had been surrendered. After the Corporation acquired its initial 50% ownership interest, the first several months of fiscal 2005 were spent reorganizing the business of H & L with new management appointed, new financing put in place, employees rehired, its Transport Canada operating certificate reinstated and new government contracts entered into.

Overview

The results of the Corporation for the three month period ended April 30, 2006 showed a net loss of $448,000 or ($0.02) per share compared to a net loss of $107,000 or ($0.01) per share for the same period a year ago. The primary reason for the change from a year ago were higher direct costs relating to salaries and benefits and flight operations support in 2006. On a year-to-date basis, the Corporation incurred a net loss of $985,000 or ($0.04) per share in 2006 compared to a net loss of $122,000 or ($0.01) per share for the same period a year ago. The net loss for the six months ended April 30, 2006 was higher than a year ago due to the same factors noted above as activities in H & L did not increase in 2005 until the second quarter when employees were rehired and the aerial forest services contracts had been awarded.

On April 6, 2006, the Corporation closed a public offering whereby the Corporation issued 7,700,000 Class A common shares at an issue price of $0.50 resulting in net proceeds of $3.1 million after share issue costs. In addition, on April 9, 2006, the Corporation entered into an agreement in principle to purchase all of the issued and outstanding shares in the capital of Great Slave Helicopters Ltd. (GSHL). Completion of the transaction is subject to a number of conditions, including all necessary regulatory and other approvals and the entering into of a definitive purchase and sale agreement with the shareholders of GSHL. The purchase price and the nature of the consideration, which is expected to be a combination of cash and shares of the Corporation, will be determined if and when a purchase and sale agreement is signed.

Revenue

Revenue for the three month period ended April 30, 2006 totalled $84,000 compared to $63,000 for the same period a year ago. On a year-to-date basis, total revenue was $106,000 compared to $63,000 a year ago. As noted above, the operations of the Corporation are seasonal in nature and services provided under the terms of the aerial forest fire contracts are typically required during the months of May to September. Revenues earned from aerial forest fire services during the second quarter related to positioning some of the aircraft and having them available for exclusive use under the contracts. The remaining aircraft will be positioned and based in the month of May with related revenues recorded at that time.

Direct Expenses

Direct expenses incurred to earn revenue consist of salaries and benefits relating to pilots and aircraft maintenance staff, aircraft maintenance and fuel costs and flight operations support. With the exception of aircraft maintenance and fuel costs, these direct expenses do not vary proportionately with revenues or hours flown; however, they have been determined to represent costs associated with earning revenue from aerial forest fire services as they would reduce significantly if the contracts were not held by H & L. During the three months ended April 30, 2006, direct expenses totalled $356,000 compared to $138,000 for the same period a year ago. Direct salaries and benefits increased as aircraft maintenance staff had been hired for the full second quarter compared to the same period a year ago when the Corporation was still reestablishing operations and rehiring staff. Direct salaries and benefits also increased from a year ago as pilots were hired and trained earlier in 2006 than in 2005 when hiring was delayed while the business of H & L was reactivated and until government contracts had been awarded. While aircraft maintenance and fuel costs for the second quarter of 2006 are comparable to 2005, costs incurred for the maintenance of aircraft during the off season were deferred and will be expensed as aircraft are utilized during the 2006 forest fire fighting season. Flight operations support for the three months ended April 30, 2006 totalled $141,000 compared to $59,000 for the same period a year ago and includes insurance costs, facilities rental, travel and other costs to support the operations of the aircraft. Flight operations support costs increased in 2006 as the business of H & L was relatively dormant in 2005 compared to 2006. On a year-to-date basis, direct costs totalled $582,000 compared to $138,000 with the primary increases due to the factors cited above.

Other Expenses

Other expenses consist of indirect salaries and benefits, property and premises expenses, interest on long-term debt and other general and administrative expenses. These expenses, which are incurred regardless of whether or not the aviation services contracts are held by H & L, totalled $396,000 for the three months ended April 30, 2006 compared to $259,000 for the same period a year ago. Other expenses were higher in the second quarter of 2006 compared to a year ago primarily as a result of interest on debt used to finance the purchase of additional aircraft during 2005 and extensive maintenance on aircraft and facilities carried out during the first six months of fiscal 2006.

On a year-to-date basis, other expenses totalled $905,000 for 2006 compared to $307,000 for the same period a year ago. Aside from higher amounts for interest on long-term debt which was discussed above, the most significant item included in other expenses is salaries and benefits which totalled $429,000 compared to $94,000 a year ago and relate to managerial positions and those required for H & L to maintain its operating certificate. Indirect salaries and benefits for the first six months of 2006 also included a charge of $280,000 for stock-based compensation relating to stock options granted in January 2006. Property and premises expense totalled $158,000 compared to $88,000 a year ago and includes amortization expense and costs relating to the operation and maintenance of premises and equipment. General and administrative expenses were $117,000 in the first six months of 2006 compared to $58,000 a year ago and include professional fees and office expenses. These last two categories of other expenses were higher than a year ago as a result of the increased business activity in H & L in the first six months of 2006 compared to what had occurred in the first six months of 2005.

Income Taxes

The Corporation uses the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes. Under the asset and liability method, future tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases. Future tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted or substantively enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect on future tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the date of enactment or substantive enactment.

For the three months ended April 30, 2006, the Corporation recorded an income tax recovery of $220,000 and on a year-to-date basis recorded a recovery of $396,000. This income tax recovery has been recorded as a result of operating losses incurred during the period. The Corporation expects that these amounts will be offset against income tax provisions recorded in the coming months when revenues are earned during the forest fire season. The Corporation's effective statutory rate approximates 36% with the income tax recovery for the three month period ended April 30, 2006 reflecting this rate. For the six months ended April 30, 2006, the rate of recovery is less than the effective statutory rate primarily because the charge for stock-based compensation was not deductible for income tax purposes.

Liquidity and Working Capital

Cash at April 30, 2006 was $2.2 million compared to $309,000 at October 31, 2005 and $99,000 a year ago. The increase from October 31, 2005 and from a year ago was due primarily to the closing of the public offering in April 2006 where 7,700,000 Class A common shares were issued for net proceeds of $3.1 million after share issue costs. A portion of these proceeds were used for operational purposes and to repay debt financing. At April 30, 2006, the Corporation had working capital of $2.2 million compared to a working capital deficiency of $983,000 at October 31, 2005 and a working capital deficiency of $848,000 a year ago. The improvement in working capital was due to the proceeds received from the closing of the public offering.

Accounts receivable at April 30, 2006 were $98,000 compared to $577,000 at October 31, 2005 and $62,000 a year ago. The decrease from October 31, 2005 was due to collection of amounts outstanding from the government with no further amounts being billed as the forest fire season had reached its conclusion. Inventory consisting of parts and supplies totalled $407,000 at April 30, 2006 compared to $385,000 at October 31, 2005 and $385,000 a year ago. Prepaid expenses and other assets increased to $1.3 million at April 30, 2006 compared to $175,000 at October 31, 2005 and $276,000 a year ago with the increase from October 31, 2005 due to the recording of recoverable income taxes during the first six months of the year as operating losses were incurred, the recording of various prepaid expense amounts and the deferral of aircraft maintenance costs. The deferred maintenance costs will be expensed during the 2006 forest fire season as aircraft are utilized.

Accounts payable and accrued liabilities were $672,000 at April 30, 2006 compared to $1,162,000 at October 31, 2005 and $735,000 a year ago. The decrease from October 31, 2005 was due primarily to the payment of amounts accrued for corporate income taxes while the amounts outstanding a year ago related primarily to outstanding payables which had accumulated when H & L had run into financial difficulty under the previous ownership and which were subsequently repaid.

The Corporation believes it has sufficient working capital to meet its operating requirements based on its existing working capital position and cash generated from operations upon commencement of the forest fire fighting season. In addition, the Corporation has available from its parent, Pacific & Western Bank of Canada, an operating line and a receivables financing program as a source of any short term financing requirements.

Capital Resources

Land, buildings and equipment at April 30, 2006 totalled $6,304,000 compared to $6,302,000 at October 31, 2005 and $5,200,000 a year ago with the increase from a year ago due primarily to additional aircraft purchased during the third quarter of 2005. Goodwill and other intangibles was $1,187,000 at April 30, 2006 compared to $1,208,000 at October 31, 2005 and $98,000 a year ago. The increase from a year ago was due to additional goodwill which arose from the acquisition of the remaining 50% of the outstanding shares of H & L. With the acquisition of additional aircraft during 2005, and with the continuing maintenance and refurbishment of aircraft, there are no requirements or plans for purchase of additional aircraft to carry out the services under the aerial forest fire contracts.

Debt Financing

Bank loan and long-term debt at April 30, 2006 totalled $5,030,000 compared to $4,370,000 at October 31, 2005 and $3,061,000 a year ago. The increase in indebtedness from a year ago was a result of additional financing required for the purchase of additional aircraft during 2005 and additional financing to carry out extensive refurbishment and maintenance of aircraft and facilities. The increase from October 31, 2005 was to finance expenditures incurred for operational purposes including maintaining and servicing the aircraft and payment of corporate income taxes.

Great Slave Helicopters Ltd.

On April 9, 2006, the Corporation entered into an agreement in principle to purchase all of the issued and outstanding shares in the capital of Great Slave Helicopters Ltd. (GSHL). Completion of the transaction is subject to a number of conditions, including all necessary regulatory and other approvals and the entering into of a definitive purchase and sale agreement with the shareholders of GSHL. The purchase price and the nature of the consideration, which is expected to be a combination of cash and shares of the Corporation, will be determined if and when a purchase and sale agreement is signed. As a result, the impact upon the Corporation cannot be determined at this time.

Shareholders' Equity

At April 30, 2006, the Corporation had 33,977,271 Class A common shares outstanding compared to 26,277,271 outstanding at October 31, 2005 with the increase due to the issue of 7,700,000 Class A common shares from the public offering which closed in April. In addition, at April 30, 2006 there were 3,365,908 common share purchase warrants outstanding entitling the holders of the warrants to subscribe for one Class A common share for every one warrant held for a subscription price of $0.11 per share and 770,000 broker warrants outstanding which were issued pursuant to the public offering. These broker warrants entitle the holder to subscribe for one Class A common share for every warrant held at a subscription price of $0.50 per share. All common share purchase warrants and broker warrants expire in 2007. At April 30, 2006, there were 2,625,000 options to acquire Class A common shares which were granted in January 2006. Salary expense and an addition to contributed surplus of $280,000 has been recognized in the financial statements relating to the vesting period of these options.

On March 27, 2006, the Corporation was continued under the Canada Business Corporations Act. At the time of the continuance, its share structure was amended to authorize the issuance of an unlimited number of Class A common voting shares and an unlimited number of Class B common variable voting shares, none of which are issued and outstanding. Each issued and outstanding common voting share as at March 27, 2006, was converted into a Class A common voting share on a one for one basis.

Additional information with respect to share capital is contained in Note 2 to the interim consolidated financial statements.

Updated Share Information

As at May 31, 2006, there were 33,987,072 Class A common shares outstanding with the change due to the exercise of common share purchase warrants after April 30, 2006. At May 31, 2006, stock options increased to 3,335,000 with the change as a result of stock options granted after April 30, 2006, and common share purchase warrants decreased to 3,356,107 with the change as a result of warrants exercised after April 30, 2006. There was no change to the number of broker warrants outstanding.

    Discovery Air Inc. (the "Corporation") was incorporated on November 12,

 1.  Significant accounting policies: 
     (a) Basis of presentation: 
         These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in
         accordance with Canadian generally accepted accounting principles
         and include the accounts of the Corporation's 100%-owned
         subsidiary, H & L. All significant intercompany balances and
         transactions have been eliminated on consolidation. 
     (b) Inventory: 
         Inventory consisting of parts and supplies is stated at the lower
         of cost, on a first-in, first-out basis, and replacement cost. 
     (c) Land, buildings and equipment 
         Land, buildings and equipment are stated at cost. Costs of
         additions and betterments are capitalized. Maintenance and repair
         expenditures which do not improve or extend productive life are
         expensed as incurred. 
         Aircraft maintenance costs incurred prior to the forest fire
         fighting season are deferred and expensed as aircraft are used. 
         Amortization is provided using the following methods and annual
         rates: 

         Asset                      Basis                Annual Rate 
         Buildings                  Straight-line                 5%
         Furniture and equipment    Diminishing balance      20%-30%
         Aircraft                   Straight-line              5.33%
         Aircraft equipment         Straight-line                20%
         Leasehold improvements     Straight-line                20%
         Vehicles                   Diminishing balance          30% 
         Aircraft and aircraft equipment are amortized during periods of
         productive use. 
     (d) Goodwill: 
         Goodwill is the residual amount that results when the purchase
         price of an acquired business exceeds the sum of the fair values
         acquired, less liabilities assumed. 
         Goodwill is not amortized and is tested for impairment annually,
         or more frequently, if events or changes in circumstances
         indicate that the asset might be impaired. 
         When the carrying amount of reporting unit goodwill exceeds the
         implied fair value of the goodwill, an impairment loss is
         recognized in an amount equal to the excess and is presented as a
         separate line item in the Consolidated Statement of Earnings. 
     (e) Intangible assets: 
         Intangible assets with finite useful lives are amortized over
         their useful lives. The amortization methods and estimated useful
         lives of intangible assets are reviewed annually. 
     (f) Impairment of long-lived assets 
         Long-lived assets, including land, building and equipment and
         purchased intangibles subject to amortization, are reviewed for
         impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate
         that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
         Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a
         comparison of the carrying amount of an asset to estimated
         undiscounted future cash flows expected to be generated by the
         asset. If the carrying amount of an asset exceeds its estimated
         future cash flows, an impairment charge is recognized by the
         amount in which the carrying amount of the asset exceeds the fair
         value of the asset. Assets to be disposed of would be separately
         presented in the balance sheet and reported at the lower of the
         carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell, and are no
         longer depreciated. The asset and liabilities of a disposed group
         classified as held for sale would be presented separately in the
         appropriate asset and liability sections of the balance sheet. 
     (g) Revenue recognition: 
         Revenue from aerial forest fire services is derived from
         government contracts and is recognized as follows: (i) revenue
         from the use of aircraft for forest fire services is recognized
         as hours are flown, (ii) basing fees for having aircraft
         available for the exclusive use of the government are recognized
         over the period of availability and (iii) fees from positioning
         and depositioning aircraft at government bases are recognized at
         the time aircraft are located to and from the bases at the
         beginning and end of the forest fire season. 
     (h) Income taxes: 
         The Corporation uses the asset and liability method of accounting
         for income taxes. Under the asset and liability method, future
         tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax
         consequences attributable to differences between the financial
         statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and
         their respective tax bases. Future tax assets and liabilities are
         measured using enacted or substantively enacted tax rates
         expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those
         temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
         The effect on future tax assets and liabilities of a change in
         tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the
         date of enactment or substantive enactment. 
     (i) Accounting estimates:

         generally accepted accounting principles requires management to

         liabilities at the dates of the financial statements and the

         Significant items subject to such estimates and assumptions

the evacuation of hundreds of people.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Sylvia Pang of the Provincial Forest Fire Service says a fire raging in the Silver Creek area near Salmon Arm has grown to two-thousand hectares.</p><p>-BODY- Smoke from the fire has forced the Shuswap Lake Hospital in Salmon Arm to evacuate around 40 seriously ill patients to other hospitals in the region.</p><p>The hospital is also considering moving about 25 other patients.</p><p>The blaze has forced the evacuation of homes on the west side of Salmon Arm.</p><p>That's in addition to about 160 homes that were evacuated in the while fighting the blaze.</p><p>Meanwhile, more than 200 residents were evacuated and several homes feared lost last night as a forest fire swept past two tiny communities on the west side of Okanagan (CP) _ Firefighters used cooler, more humid weather to their advantage Thursday after a forest fire forced the evacuation of a northern Alberta hamlet.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The weather's turned around for us a little bit,'' said provincial forestry spokesman Rick Strickland.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>About 275 residents of Fort MacKay and a nearby native reserve, along with 60 Canadian National Resource Limited oil workers remained out of their homes Thursday. They were bused Wednesday to Fort McMurray, about 50 kilometres south, when the forest fire raged to within five kilometres of the area.</p><p>Many of those who fled their homes stayed with relatives and friends in Fort McMurray, while about a dozen people spent another night in tents pitched on the floor of the Frank Lacroix Minor Hockey Arena.</p><p>"I'm just anxious because I want to go home,'' said Jennifer Courtorielle, 33, who spent Thursday night with her family in a hotel. But for the sake of her 15-month-old daughter, she'd rather stay in Fort McMurray.</p><p>"It was better to leave.''</p><p>It is not known when the residents will be able to return to their homes.</p><p>"We've got people there prepared for the worst,'' said Fort MacKay First Nations Chief Jim Boucher.</p><p>"I'm quite confident in terms of our ability to save the community.''</p><p>Highway 63, the only road into the community, was reopened Thursday morning. The Mildred Lake airstrip remained closed.</p><p>Cooler conditions Wednesday night and Thursday allowed officials to re-assess how much boreal forest was blackened.</p><p>The amount of forest and land burned was reduced to half a square kilometre, down from the original estimate of 1.4 square kilometres Wednesday, said Terry Cunha, spokesman for Alberta Sustainable Resource Development.</p><p>"(Wednesday) the conditions were very extreme and the smoke was very thick and it was prohibiting our chances of scanning the fire,'' said Cunha.</p><p>Cunha said they were able to do some aerial surveying to get a better idea of the fire's size.</p><p>The inferno was being fought by 80 firefighters _ some from as far away as Calgary and Fort Chipewyan _ six helicopters, nine bulldozers, heavy equipment and three water bomber groups.</p><p>Officials still don't know whether the fire was started by lightning or human activity, he said.</p><p>Strong winds were fanning the fire westward when residents of the tiny hamlet of Fort MacKay were ordered to leave, said provincial fire officials.</p><p>However, wind direction changed overnight and blew the fire toward the Athabasca River.</p><p>"(It's) a fairly wide river and it's a good break for us,'' said Strickland.</p><p>As well, temperatures fell 10 degrees to about 20 C and humidity also rose significantly.</p><p>"Things are looking a little bit better for us today,'' Strickland said.</p><p>The fire is still out of control but it has not moved closer to the community, said Cunha.</p><p>As a precaution, the hamlet's fire department and workers from neighbouring oilsands companies were installing sprinkler systems on homes. By Thursday evening bulldozers had already cut a trench around the town.</p><p>"It is all about reducing the risk of the fire getting into the community,'' said Cunha.</p><p>RCMP Insp. Peter Clark said four officers were patrolling the town at any given time to prevent looting.</p><p>Another forest fire near Prince Albert, Sask., north of Saskatoon, was burning out of control Thursday. It has consumed nearly four square kilometres of forest, but there have not been any evacuations from surrounding communities.</p><p>(Edmonton Sun)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
